benchmark_details.name: Radar (RobustAndDataAwareReasoning)
benchmark_details.overview: Radar is a benchmark for systematically evaluating data-aware reasoning on tabular data. It focuses on the ability of language models to handle real-world data artifacts such as missing values, outliers, and inconsistencies, assessing their reasoning capabilities under various perturbations and table sizes.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To provide a structured evaluation framework that highlights language models' abilities to reason over imperfect tabular data.

data.source: Crowdsourced from various domains, including education, health, and business, drawing on diverse datasets.
data.annotation: Manually annotated by data science experts.

methodology.calculation: Exact match is calculated based on the ability of the models to correctly respond to queries over perturbed tabular data.
methodology.interpretation: Higher exact match scores indicate better performance in recognizing and reasoning about data artifacts.
methodology.baseline_results: Performance varies by model; frontier models show significant performance drops on perturbed data compared to clean data.
methodology.validation: Evaluated using a series of perturbations that simulate real-world data artifacts and by measuring performance across varying table sizes.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.data_licensing: The datasets are sourced from various publicly available, licensed datasets.
